key_details.ASCVD: Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (a condition where plaque builds up in your arteries, narrowing them and making it harder for blood to flow through)
key_details.BUN/Creatinine: blood tests that measure kidney function
key_details.Bimanual examination: an exam where the doctor uses both hands to feel your internal organs
key_details.Bunionectomy: surgery to remove a bony bump on your toe
key_details.Carotid artery upstroke: the feeling of your pulse in your neck arteries
key_details.Cranial nerves II-XII: the twelve pairs of nerves that come directly from your brain
key_details.Fibrocystic breast disease: a common condition where your breasts feel lumpy or rope-like
key_details.Fundoscopic examination: eye exam using a special light to look at the back of your eye
key_details.GERD: acid reflux, where stomach acid comes back up into your esophagus
key_details.Gastro-esophageal reflux disease: a condition where stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach
key_details.HMG Co-reductases: a class of cholesterol-lowering medications, also known as statins
key_details.Jugular venous pressure: the pressure in the veins of your neck, which can show how well your heart is pumping
key_details.Motor and sensory examination: tests of your muscle strength, movement, and ability to feel sensations
key_details.PMI: Point of Maximal Impulse (the strongest point where your heart beat can be felt on your chest)
key_details.Pelvic examination: an exam of your female reproductive organs
key_details.Peripheral pulses: pulses felt in your arms and legs
key_details.TAH with BSO: Total Abdominal Hysterectomy with Bilateral Salpingo-Oophorectomy (surgery to remove your uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries through an incision in your abdomen)
key_details.angina pectoris: chest pain due to reduced blood flow to the heart muscle
key_details.anterior tibial: relating to the front of the shin
key_details.aortic stenosis: narrowing of the aortic valve, which controls blood flow from your heart to your body
key_details.aspirin: a medication that thins your blood
key_details.baseline EKG: a recording of your heart's electrical activity taken as a starting point
key_details.bruits: unusual whooshing sounds heard over blood vessels
key_details.cardiac catheterization: a procedure where a thin, flexible tube is inserted into a blood vessel and guided to your heart to diagnose or treat heart conditions
key_details.cerebellar function: the part of your brain that controls balance and coordination
key_details.cholesterol: a waxy, fat-like substance found in your blood
key_details.cimetidine: a medication used to treat stomach ulcers
key_details.claudication: cramping pain in your leg muscles, usually during exercise, due to poor blood flow
key_details.clubbing: changes in the shape of your fingers and nails, often related to lung or heart disease
key_details.congestive heart failure: a condition where your heart can't pump enough blood to meet your body's needs
key_details.coronary artery disease: narrowing or blockage of the arteries that supply blood to the heart
key_details.crackles: crackling sounds heard in your lungs, like Rice Krispies
key_details.cyanosis: bluish discoloration of the skin due to lack of oxygen
key_details.diuretics: medications that help your body get rid of excess fluid
key_details.dorsalis pedis: relating to the top of the foot
key_details.electrolytes: minerals in your blood and other body fluids that have an electric charge
key_details.epigastric pain: pain in the upper middle part of your abdomen, below your ribs
key_details.exertional dyspnea: difficulty breathing when you do physical activity
key_details.femoral: relating to the thigh or groin
key_details.guaiac negative: no hidden blood found in your stool
key_details.hives: itchy, raised welts on the skin
key_details.hypertensive retinopathy: damage to the blood vessels in your eye caused by high blood pressure
key_details.impending myocardial infarction: a heart attack about to happen
key_details.ischemic cardiac origin: caused by a lack of blood flow to the heart
key_details.left ventricular dysfunction: when the main pumping chamber of your heart (the left ventricle) isn't working as well as it should
key_details.left ventricular hypertrophy: enlargement and thickening of the main pumping chamber of your heart
key_details.liver span: the size of your liver as measured by tapping
key_details.mid clavicular line: an imaginary line down the middle of your collarbone
key_details.myocardial ischemia: lack of blood flow and oxygen to the heart muscle
key_details.nitrates: medications that widen your blood vessels to improve blood flow and relieve chest pain
key_details.nocturia: waking up at night to urinate
key_details.non-invasive tests: medical tests that do not involve breaking the skin or entering the body
key_details.palpitations: feeling your heart beat unusually fast or hard
key_details.para-sternal area: the area next to your breastbone
key_details.paraumbilical area: the area around your belly button
key_details.paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea: sudden episodes of difficulty breathing that wake you up at night
key_details.peptic ulcer disease: sores in the lining of your stomach or small intestine
key_details.percussion: tapping on your body to listen to the sounds
key_details.platelet inhibitors: medications that prevent blood clots, like aspirin
key_details.popliteal: relating to the back of the knee
key_details.premature CAD: early-onset coronary artery disease (heart disease where blood vessels become narrowed)
key_details.pretest probability: the likelihood of a condition being present before any tests are done
key_details.pulmonary component: a problem related to your lungs
key_details.radial areas: relating to the forearm or wrist
key_details.rectal sphincter tone: the tightness of the muscle that controls your rectum
key_details.renal artery: artery that supplies blood to your kidney
key_details.renovascular hypertension: high blood pressure caused by narrowing of the arteries to your kidneys
key_details.second right inter-costal space: the space between your second and third ribs on the right side of your chest
key_details.secondary cause of hypertension: high blood pressure caused by another medical condition
key_details.speculum examination: an exam using a tool to widen the vagina
key_details.systolic decrescendo murmur: a specific type of abnormal heart sound heard when your heart contracts and fades away
key_details.telemetry floor: a hospital unit where your heart rhythm is continuously monitored
key_details.third heart sound: an extra, abnormal sound heard during heart relaxation, often a sign of heart issues
key_details.thyroid gland: a gland in your neck that produces hormones
key_details.unstable angina: a serious type of chest pain that can happen at rest and is a warning sign of a heart attack
key_details.ventriculogram: an imaging test that takes pictures of your heart's pumping chambers
key_details.volume overload: too much fluid in your body
key_details.wall motion abnormalities: parts of your heart muscle not moving properly

personal_takeaways: This summary is for Pamela Rogers, the patient described in the medical report. You're experiencing chest pain, called angina, which we believe is because your heart isn't getting enough blood. Because your pain is getting worse and happening even when you're resting, we're very concerned about 'unstable angina,' which means we need to treat it quickly to prevent a heart attack. You have several risk factors, including high blood pressure, a family history of heart disease, and having your ovaries removed early. We've also noticed some fluid in your lungs and an unusual heart sound, suggesting your heart might not be pumping fluid as strongly as it should. There's also a possibility that your high blood pressure could be linked to the blood vessels in your kidneys. Our plan involves keeping you in the hospital to monitor your heart closely, giving you medications to help your heart and prevent blood clots, helping you get rid of extra fluid, and performing a procedure called a 'cardiac catheterization' to directly examine the blood vessels in your heart and assess how well it's pumping. We'll also check your cholesterol and discuss healthy lifestyle changes for when you go home.

1. Take Aspirin.action: Take aspirin regularly as prescribed by your doctor.
1. Take Aspirin.purpose: This medicine helps prevent blood clots and reduces the risk of a heart attack.

10. Attend Lab Tests.action: Go for your scheduled blood tests (like BUN/Creatinine and electrolytes) and EKG.
10. Attend Lab Tests.purpose: These tests help your doctor check your kidney function, body chemicals, and heart's electrical activity.

2. Use Nitrates for Chest Pain.action: Take nitrates as instructed by your doctor, especially if you experience chest pain. If pain continues after taking nitrates, tell your medical team right away.
2. Use Nitrates for Chest Pain.purpose: Nitrates help widen your blood vessels to improve blood flow to your heart and relieve chest pain.

3. Monitor Your Cholesterol.action: Get your cholesterol levels checked regularly as scheduled by your doctor.
3. Monitor Your Cholesterol.purpose: This helps make sure your cholesterol is at a healthy level for your heart.

4. Start an Exercise Program.action: Begin and consistently follow the exercise plan given to you by your doctor or physical therapist.
4. Start an Exercise Program.purpose: Regular exercise is important for your heart and overall health.

5. Follow a Weight Loss Program.action: Follow the weight loss program recommended by your doctor.
5. Follow a Weight Loss Program.purpose: Managing your weight is crucial for your heart health.

6. Eat a Low-Fat Diet.action: Choose foods that are low in fat.
6. Eat a Low-Fat Diet.purpose: A low-fat diet is very important for lowering cholesterol and supporting your heart health.

7. Consider Cholesterol Medicine (Statin.action: If your cholesterol is high, your doctor may prescribe a cholesterol-lowering medication, sometimes called a statin. Take it exactly as directed.
7. Consider Cholesterol Medicine (Statin.purpose: This medicine helps lower unhealthy cholesterol levels in your body.

8. Schedule Your Heart Catheterization.action: Attend your appointment to schedule the cardiac catheterization procedure.
8. Schedule Your Heart Catheterization.purpose: This procedure allows doctors to look closely at the blood vessels around your heart.

9. Take Diuretics for Breathing.action: Take your diuretic medication exactly as prescribed.
9. Take Diuretics for Breathing.purpose: Diuretics help your body get rid of excess fluid, which can make breathing easier and help lower blood pressure.
